data.text: Contents
Clinical areas where there may be a special arrangement ........................................... 8
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust recognises that providing flexible visiting times offer important opportunities for patients and their relatives to remain in contact throughout their hospital stay.
This policy will provide a structure for staff and patients and visitors which;

Supports the patient in hospital from the people who matter to them. We may sometimes need to limit the numbers of family members who can visit at any one time, so physical distancing rules can be followed.
Conversations with the patient and family will take place on admission and throughout the hospital stay to discuss who they would like to visit and when.

Family support at times when patients wish the presence, help and support of the people who matter to them. For example at mealtimes, rehabilitation sessions, discharge planning and during Multi-disciplinary Team conversations.

While COVID-19 is still with us, to maintain the safety of patients, family providing support and staff, visiting needs to continue to be carefully managed and to limit numbers of people visiting at any one time. If you wish to visit anyone in these hospitals, please contact the ward to arrange a visit in advance, so we can be sure our wards and hospital sites do not become overcrowded and allow everyone to follow the physical distancing rules.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To keep our visitors and staff safe, protect our vulnerable patients and limit the spread of COVID-19, we continue to restrict the number of people allowed on to our hospital sites.

We know that it's hugely important for patients to see their loved ones while they are in hospital, so are doing all we can to support people to keep in contact while keeping everyone as safe as possible. We will continue to review our visiting arrangements in line with guidance from Public Health England, NHS England and NHS Improvement.
We welcome support from family and friends in hospital; we know that this is a vital support to patients, not least with nutrition, healing, recovery, and overall quality of care.
Definitions

table_items.text: Giving relatives/visitor more opportunity to visit their families during their admission in hospital.
Any person who comes to visit a patient and is not there in a professional capacity.
Arrangements made with an individual visitor and the Nurse in charge of the ward to facilitate visiting outside normal visiting hours due to an extraordinary set of circumstances.
Any instances whereby visiting is prohibited due to extraordinary set of circumstances.

A carer is someone who, by looking after a frail, ill or disabled partner, relative, friend or neighbour, enables them to stay at home, or to return to it. Without the carer's care, the cared-for person might remain longer in hospital than necessary, or be in intermediate or transitional care, or in a residential or nursing home.
When the patient is the source of the infection (formerly barrier nursing)
When the patient requires protection i.e. immunocompromised (formerly reverse barrier nursing)

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief Executive and wider Trust Board have key roles and are responsible for:
4.1.1 Ensuring that the Trust meets requirements set out by statutory and regulatory authorities such as the Department of Health, Commissioners and the Care Quality Commission
4.1.2 Ensuring that processes are in place so that: o clinical staff are aware of this policy and adhere to its requirements of appropriate resources exist to meet the requirements of this policy.
4.1.3 The Caldecott Guardian is to ensure patient confidentiality is maintained at all times through the development and management of policies and procedures.
The Executive Directors are responsible for:
4.2.1  Ensuring that all operational managers in their area are aware of this policy, understand its requirements and support its implementation with relevant staff.
The Associate Medical Director and Consultants are responsible for:
4.3.1  Ensuring procedures are understood and carried out by medical staff involved in the implementation of this policy
Senior Matrons/ Matrons/ Site Co-ordinators are responsible for
4.4.1 Monitoring open visiting times in accordance with the agreed Trust Policy
4.4.2 Providing support in dealing with difficult / complex circumstances / situations for Ward/Department Managers or the Nurse in Charge during the night.
Ward/Unit Matrons and Managers are responsible for:
4.5.1 Ensuring that staff carry out the duties prescribed in this policy
4.5.2 Ensuring that patients and relatives are aware of the open visiting times
4.5.3 Making judgement for exclusions to this policy
4.5.4 Monitoring of visitor numbers during visiting times
Ward Staff are responsible for
4.6.1  Ensuring Patients and Visitors are informed of the Trust agreed Visiting times
Communications Team is responsible for
4.7.1  Ensuring this policy is communicated within the Trust and to external stakeholders
General information for visitors

Visiting times are between 2-3pm and 6-7pm and each patient is allowed two visitors. However, to ensure we can maintain social distancing we will only be able to have two visitors in a bay - which may contain 4-6 beds - at any one time, so this will need to be by prior arrangement with ward staff. Please note these may change based on national and local needs.

Not all patients can bring a visitor when attending the emergency department. To ensure the safety of both staff and patients only vulnerable patients who require complex/difficult decision making may be accompanied by one close family contact, or somebody important to the patient, to support them. This applies to outpatients and diagnostic settings as well. Please note these may change based on national and local needs.
All visitors will be made to feel welcome by staff when they arrive on the ward.
All staff will treat visitors with politeness, dignity and respect.
Respect the visiting policy.
Observe confidentiality.
Visitors will be advised that; Patients and their family / visitors should decide on a spokesperson to liaise with medical and nursing staff regarding care, treatment and progress of the patient.
5.7.1 All visitors should treat staff with respect and politeness.
5.7.2 Visitors should only visit during the designated open visiting times unless alternate arrangements have been agreed with the Ward Manager / Nurse in charge due to extenuating circumstances.

5.7.3 Children/Babies under the age of 12 will only visit at the discretion of the nurse in charge. Visitors need to be made aware that if they have children accompanying them or visitors who are children need to see the nurse in charge when visiting on the wards.
5.7.4 Visitors must be responsible for the safety and security of their belongings.
5.7.5 Visitors will not use mobile phones, cameras and camcorders in restricted areas in accordance with the related trust policies and guidelines.
5.7.6 As clear surfaces promote good access for cleaning staff, visitors should be asked not to bring excessive or unnecessary items into hospital or place them on the patient's locker top.
Administration
Example visiting times will be clearly displayed outside each ward
It is advisable no children under 12 should visit and the only exceptions should be if either parent is the patient. In all cases, advice should be sought from the Nurse in charge.

The duration of visits or number of visitors may be limited by the Nurse in charge if it is felt to be in the best interest of the patient and will be at the discretion of the Ward Manager / Deputy Ward Manager or Nurse in Charge if it is felt to be detrimental to the patient's wellbeing.
Visiting outside visiting hours

In cases where visitors or patients may experience difficulty in complying with the advertised visiting times on grounds of disability, religious beliefs or other personal reasons, their requirements should be accommodated where it is reasonably possible, without compromising either health and safety or infection control issues.
Clinical areas where there may be a special arrangement
If there is a need to restrict visiting to a particular ward or area for example due to an outbreak of COVID-19 or rapidly increasing community transmission, essential visits will continue.
Examples of the type of situations where “essential visiting” is possible are as follows:
A birth partner supporting a woman during hospital visits.
A person receiving end-of-life care – Where patients are entering their last days of life, two visitors can be with them at all times.
To support someone with a mental health issue, dementia, a learning disability or autism, where not being present would cause the patient to be distressed.
To accompany a child in hospital, both parents are able to visit.
Role of the carer (paid and unpaid or family carer)
NHSE guidance on visiting states that visitors and carers should not be seen as one. The role of the carer is unique and is key to patient recovery.

All patients requiring potential external care support should have their needs risk assessed by the ward in liaison with relevant specialist nurse advisors to assess what is needed and in what capacity.

Information on the patient can and should be gathered via conversations with family and relevant carers as well utilising key documents such as Hospital Passports, Carers passport and This is me document.
Carers are to liaise with the Nurse in Charge of the department to agree a plan.
Click here to open the carers policy
Special circumstances when visiting is restricted

There may be occasions where it is necessary to restrict, monitor or suspend visitation when patients are subject to a safeguarding investigation. This will be assessed on a case by case basis and overseen by the safeguarding team. This decision will always be left to the service user, however, in cases where they are assessed as lacking in capacity under the Mental Capacity Act (2005) this decision will be made in their best interests by clinical staff.
Restrictions to visiting may be put in place for infection prevention and control purposes on the recommendation of the clinical or Infection Prevention and Control team.
Virtual visiting
Face to Face visiting is limited to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission so please keep in touch with friends and family during their hospital staff by phone and video using mobile devices.
Visitors can drop off phones, tablets and other belongings for a family member or friend in hospital at the hospital. The property remains the responsibility of the patient.

If the ward is a RED AREA and there are no visiting arrangements, drop off must be discussed with the ward. If your family member or friend doesn't have their own device or needs support in communicating with relatives and friends, we are able to help.
Clinical team to ensure process in place to ensure trust owned devices are cleaned appropriately.
Clinician or team with responsibility for the trust owned device to ensure that patient's calls are managed safely and appropriately and that the device is stored in a safe accessible area.
Digital services will be responsible for procuring the devices and ensuring the correct set up of each trust owned device.
The ICC, via a nominated ‘owner' will be responsible for ensuring the trust owned devices are appropriately charged and stored and will hold the device for distribution as required.
All trust owned devices will need to be set up with appropriate apps, and be run via the public Wi-Fi to facilitate and allow face to face calls for patients and their relatives/ loved ones.
Consent and capacity
All patients need to be fully aware of any precautions required and potential risks of using the device. Their consent to use the trust owned device must be documented within the patients notes.
If a staff member is facilitating the call, they need to ensure that patients are fully aware and understand the information, either verbally and/or in written communication.
Where a patient lacks the capacity to make this decision staff are to document this and why they feel that the facilitation of the call is in the best interests of the patient.
The outgoing number must relate to the number on our PAS as the patients next of kin.
Confidentiality, dignity and respect
Only outgoing calls can be made using the trust owned device.
The purpose of the call is NOT to share medical information; usual procedures for the updating of relatives by a clinician are to be followed.
Video communications are securely encrypted.
No aspect of the communication will be digitally recorded.
The responsible nurse is to ensure where possible the patient has privacy when making the call; the nurse may be needed to support the use of the device and facilitate the call.
Safeguarding issues
For those patients that lack capacity staff should be facilitating the call at all times.
If staff are concerned about the safety of patients at any time they are to follow the usual adult safeguarding policies and procedures.
During any communications and or patient interactions staff are to follow the appropriate PPE guidelines for their own protection.

Before and after each use of the trust owned device, thoroughly clean the device using Clinell wipes or a suitable alternative. Use a green clean sticker to confirm the device has been decontaminated. Ensure that the front and back of the device are wiped starting from the top working to the bottom.
Storage

The trust owned devices will be held within the appropriate allocated teams across the trust. They are to be kept in secure place within the designated areas listed below that can still be accessed by the nurse in charge/ duty Matron out of hours.
Nominated ‘Owner' of trust owned devices
This will be a senior member of staff who will be able to manage these devices and ensure they are used appropriately when required.
Prior to virtual visiting the member of staff facilitating the call will explain what to expect.

Unfortunately, we can't allow you to ‘record' any of the visit or take any photos or screen shots during the visit without the patient's consent. This is to protect the privacy of patients in the hospital.
Virtual visiting will be offered when it's safe and appropriate to do this. This means it' not always possible for us to call you at the time we may have agreed to do this.
Feedback from patients and their family members that are using virtual visiting are finding it helpful and reassuring.
Infection Prevention and Control
COVID-19 is still with us and can be transmitted easily. To reduce risks careful attention to infection prevention and control measures around family support still need to be maintained.

There are many vulnerable patients in our hospital wards and in particular, some types of illness and types of treatments where we need to proceed with extreme caution, ensure a risk assessment is undertaken appropriately, and reassessed as and when circumstances change.

A consultant led, multi-disciplinary team (MDT) individual risk assessment is advised for high-risk patients to aid decision making to determine whether visits can be safely supported or not. Some examples of patients who would require this review would be those undergoing surgery or patients with low immunity.
If a visit is not possible, we will provide you with an explanation why this is necessary. We will keep this under review where possible and will reassess as circumstances change.
We will keep these restrictions under constant review as the national guidance continues to change.

If a visitor is unwell (Covid-19 , diarrhoea or vomiting, flu like symptoms or any infectious condition), or has been in contact with anyone with these symptoms prior to coming to visit, they are advised not to visit until they are  hours clear of symptoms. Contact the IPCT for further advice.
Visitors must wear a face covering and use the alcohol sanitiser / gel to clean their hands on entering and leaving the clinical area / ward.
All visitors are required to wear PPE, i.e. gloves, aprons, masks, as relevant, when assisting with direct patient care during their visit.
Visitors are not to sit on the beds as this is a cross contamination risk, if unable to find a chair to ask a member of staff for help.
Visitors are not allowed onto wards where patients have been isolating prior to admission.
Visitors are asked to help keep our hospital clean and inform staff of any cleaning concerns.
Visitors must be advised not to touch drips, drains, wound sites or dressings.
Visitors should only bring in food items for patients following discussion with the Nurse in charge.
Visitors are to be advised of any precautionary actions to take when visiting patients who require source isolation or protective isolation.
Registering when they attend so we have a record of who has been on the ward. (signing in as they enter the ward and signing out when exiting the ward)

Green Wards – any carers accessing Green wards should be made aware of infection control measures in place and are expected to comply with these measures at all times. (Gloves, face mask etc.) These are elective patients only and should not have visitors where possible.

Amber Wards - any carers accessing Amber wards should be made aware of the ward status and risks that they potentially face by being on these wards, they should also be made aware of infection control measures in place and are expected to comply with these measures at all times. (Gloves, face mask etc.)

Red Wards – Assessment of risks and need for patients on these wards needs to be robust and very clear ensuring that any access that is needed for carers to support is essential. For these wards we are potentially talking about situations where the patient in question is under a mental health section that needs to be upheld by a relevant mental health professional, patients with extreme behaviour issues or complex physical health needs that can't be met by the wards. Where it is felt that patient needs carer support on these wards then they should be made aware of the relevant risks to themselves and also the strict infection control measures they need to abide by.
Decision on who gains access to ED or the ward, outside visiting hours should sit with the ward, department senior nurses on that day.
Please refer to MSEPO-20256 Outbreak policy in the event of ward closure due to an outbreak of infection.
Training requirements
Trust statutory and mandatory training to be completed.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Monitoring will be carried out continuously and any difficult instances will be reported through the Matrons to the Associate Director of Nursing / Director of Nursing. These will be documented and collated to be taken into consideration at the Professional Nursing and Midwifery Forum as and when instances occur.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Frequency of the monitorin g activity
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Directors of Nursing, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve MSE guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Directors of Nursing of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)

☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Updating the visiting policy to reflect a consistent approach across the Mid and South Essex Trust sites.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To reflect a consistent approach across the Mid and South Essex Trust sites.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff and the public have a consistent and up to date policy that reflects recent changes due to COVID 19.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No, the guidelines are written in line with National Guidelines. Reasonable adjustments are made for those individuals affected by EOL, and Health Inequalities.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
